verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt; after that, he will let you go from here. When he lets you go, he will surely drive you out of here completely.
verses.comment: The phrase ‘drive you out of here completely’ reflects the strong Hebrew expression ‘he will certainly thrust you out’.

verses.text: Speak now in the hearing of the people, that every man should ask from his neighbor and every woman from her neighbor for articles of silver and articles of gold.”
verses.comment: ‘Articles’ translates the Hebrew ‘kli’, meaning ‘objects’ or ‘vessels’, generally understood to mean ‘jewelry’ or ‘valuables’ here.

verses.text: And the LORD gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians. Moreover, the man Moses was very great in the land of Egypt, in the eyes of Pharaoh’s servants and in the eyes of the people.
verses.comment: ‘Very great’ is a literal translation (‘gadol me'od’).

verses.text: So Moses said, “This is what the LORD says: About midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt,
verses.comment: ‘About midnight’ means literally 'around the middle of the night.'

verses.text: and every firstborn in the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sits on his throne, even to the firstborn of the slave girl who is at her millstone; and all the firstborn of the cattle as well.
verses.comment: ‘Slave girl at her millstone’ refers to the lowest social class, grinding grain.

verses.text: There will be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt, such as there has never been, nor will ever be again.
verses.comment: ‘Cry’ is the same word used for the Israelites’ earlier suffering in Egypt (Ex. 3:7).

verses.text: But not even a dog will bark against any of the people of Israel, either man or animal, so that you may know that the LORD distinguishes between Egypt and Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Not even a dog will bark’ is a Hebrew expression for perfect peace or no harm.

verses.text: All these your servants will come down to me and bow before me, saying, ‘Go out, you and all the people who follow you!’ After that I will go out.” And he went out from Pharaoh in hot anger.
verses.comment: ‘In hot anger’ (Hebrew: ‘with burning anger’), describing Moses’ emotional response.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.”
verses.comment: ‘My wonders’ refers to the miracles and plagues God performs in Egypt.

verses.text: Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not let the people of Israel go out of his land.
verses.comment: ‘Hardened Pharaoh's heart’ keeps the literal Hebrew expression with its theological significance.
